repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
See https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/pull/3573#pullrequestreview-1132968510 for the motivation.

This seems to work and I'll try to add some actual tests later to make sure it does.

#### Example usage:

`c/injections.scm`
```scheme
;; preproc_arg gets injected as c
(preproc_arg) @self
```

`cpp/injections.scm`
```scheme
; inherits: c
;; preproc_arg gets injected as cpp
```

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
            lang = name == 'self' and self:lang() or name
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -388,7 +388,11 @@ function LanguageTree:_get_injections()
           -- Allows for other tags to be used in matches
         elseif string.sub(name, 1, 1) ~= '_' then
           if not lang then
-            lang = name
+            if name == 'self' then
+              lang = self:lang()
+            else
+              lang = name
+            end

comment_regular_data.body: Should be good providing we never have a tree-sitter language called `self`. We could maybe uppercase it to `SELF` (or similar) to signify that it's not a normal language.
The other special captures like `@combined` aren't uppercase either.
Might be something to reconsider? @clason
Are capture names case sensitive always? (Highlight groups are not.)

Haven't checked, changing case was just one suggestion. The main point was doing something to better distinguish languages from meta stuff (bikeshedding aside).

We could even do something like `@meta.self` or `@_self`.

Or just keep things as they are and have special words.

> The main point was doing something to better distinguish languages from meta stuff (bikeshedding aside).

That is a good point (and also applies to `@conceal` and `@spell`).

I think I would prefer `@_self`, as "underscore means internal" is a more widely used pattern.
`@_self` may be used in queries to match the `self` keyword in languages like Lua or Python.

Ah, that's right, nvim-treesitter allows bypassing the Capture Police via `@_`. 

How many "special captures" are we talking about? Is there a list?

### Highlights

- `@conceal`
- `@spell`

### Injections

- `@language`
- `@content`
- `@combined`
- `@self` (?)

---

I think that's all of them.

I'd hate to touch the special highlight captures; that would be (too) breaking.

I agree that making them stand out as special would be a good idea, but it's not enough benefit for triggering downstream breaking changes right now. Let's go with `@self` for now -- if somebody is foolish enough to create a SELF language, we'll just have to name the parser `selflang`.

There is already a [self language](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self_(programming_language)), and has been since the 80s ☹️. It's one of the early object oriented languages. I couldn't find a tree-sitter parser for it and I don't know how commonly used it still is (latest release in 2017), but that's something to keep in mind.

I think naming a future parser selflang makes sense.

After some thinking about this: we could implement this feature in nvim-treesitter with a custom directive (`self-injection! @_self` where we provide the implementation for `self-injection`). This would maybe be less invasive than this change in core.
As highlighting is now "owned" by core, this should be done here unless there's a plan for iterating a lot.

We can always name the capture something else, like `@parent`.
Surely there's no "parent" language…right?

What about `@nvim.self`, `@nvim.conceal`, etc. ?  It's pretty obvious that these captures are internal or specific to neovim. 
Also, `@nvim` could be used as a namespace for future features without worrying about conflicts with other queries.

> What about `@nvim.self`, `@nvim.conceal`, etc. ? It's pretty obvious that these captures are internal or specific to neovim. Also, `@nvim` could be used as a namespace for future features without worrying about conflicts with other queries.

I like this. I think we should do it.
It's a fine idea but it would require changing the existing captures both here and in every treesitter-related plugin.
Yes it would. We can support both while downstream migrates.

So, should I use `@nvim.self` for the capture?
Also, can anyone help me figure out [this](#issuecomment-1282445137) issue?
I think we want to bank this until we can coordinate this with Helix (as part of the grand Conjunction of the Queries).
Due to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/22518. We may need to rethink this.

Injection format PR is merged; going forward this is the only supported format (so new features will not be supported by the old format).

This means we could use `(#set! injection.language.self)` and avoid conflict with any language name.

Although I'm skeptical that this actually has a pressing use case; the two injection files mentioned in the linked PR are tiny (two queries each), so combining them doesn't really offset the cost of the new feature?

> Although I'm skeptical that this actually has a pressing use case; the two injection files mentioned in the linked PR are tiny (two queries each), so combining them doesn't really offset the cost of the new feature?

It's necessary for nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter#3573.

Could you summarize the key issue in this PR (ideally commit) description? Otherwise it becomes hard to discuss it here.

If I understand it correctly, the _actual_ issue (which is not the example usage you gave!) is that you have the injection chains
```
lang A -> lang B -> lang A
lang C -> lang B -> lang C
...
```
but the queries for lang B don't know where it was injected into?

Then `injection.language.self` is wrong (or at least misleading); should be `injection.language.parent` instead.

Let's say we have languages `A` and `B` where `B` extends `A` and
that there's a `foo` node (e.g. preprocessor argument or string
interpolation) which requires an injection of the language itself.
The issue here is that `B` cannot simply inherit from `A` because
`foo` would be injected as `A` when it should be injected as `B`.

Any chance the new injection method has already solved this?

> The issue here is that B cannot simply inherit from A because
foo would be injected as A when it should be injected as B.

Then you don't inherit the injections, period; for the given example (c and cpp) where it's just a single query, I don't see the need to add new features to save two or three lines of runtime file?

I consider the parent injection a much stronger use case. (And if we add that, we might as well add `self`, granted -- if Helix is also fine with it.)

> Any chance the new injection method has already solved this?

I don't see how? That's just about how you specify the injections.

> Then you don't inherit the injections, period; for the given example (c and cpp) where it's just a single query, I don't see the need to add new features to save two or three lines of runtime file?

nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter#3573 adds a lot more queries to them. :)

> I don't see how? That's just about how you specify the injections.

Perhaps by allowing inherited queries to be overwritten.

I've updated this for the new format.
```clojure
(preproc_def (preproc_arg) @injection.content (#set! injection.self))
```
I'm not too keen on adding this unless we can get this recognized by upstream.
Maybe @amaanq can help with that.
I wouldn't mind adding that upstream

https://github.com/tree-sitter/tree-sitter/pull/2529

Wondering if just `@injection.self` would be better

title: feat(treesitter): support self injection
